title:
Efficient calibration of the shifted square-root diffusion model to
  credit default swap spreads using asymptotic approximations

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We derive a closed-form approximation for the credit default swap (CDS) spread in the two-dimensional shifted square-root diffusion (SSRD) model using asymptotic coefficient expansion technique to approximate solutions of nonlinear partial differential equations. Specifically, we identify the Cauchy problems associated with two terms in the CDS spread formula that lack analytical solutions and derive asymptotic approximations for these terms. Our approximation does not require the assumption of uncorrelated interest rate and default intensity processes as typically required for calibration in the SSRD model. Through several calibration studies using market data on CDS spread, we demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of our proposed formula.


Keywords: Credit default swap; Shifted square-root diffusion model; Asymptotic coefficient expansion JEL Classification: C600, G130
2010 MSC: 65C30, 91G40

## 1 Introduction

In this work, we apply the asymptotic coefficient expansion method of Lorig et al. (2015) for nonlinear partial differential equations (PDEs) to derive an approximate formula for credit default swap (CDS) spread under the two-dimensional shifted square-root diffusion (SSRD) model of Brigo and Alfonsi (2005), within a stochastic intensity framework. Unlike the original approach, which assumed uncorrelated interest rate and default intensity factors for calibration, we derive our approximation formula and subsequently propose a calibration strategy, without assuming such a condition. Through extensive numerical studies, we show that our approximation formula allows fast calibration to market data and provides accurate estimates of CDS spreads and related survival probabilities.

The two-dimensional SSRD model is based on the generalised square-root diffusion model introduced by Duffie and Singleton (1999), where both interest rate and default intensity are modelled as Cox-Ingersoll-Ross (CIR) processes. A key feature of the SSRD model is its ability to separate the calibration of interest rate and default intensity processes using bond price and credit spread data. The model has gained significant attention and has been extended in later research. For example, Brigo and Cousot (2006) demonstrated its effectiveness in capturing implied volatility patterns in CDS options and compared its performance to a term structure market model. Brigo and El-Bachir (2006) further enhanced the model

by adding jumps to the stochastic intensity process, enabling better calibration to default swaptions across various strikes and maturities. Later, Brigo and El-Bachir (2010) advanced analytical tractability of the extended SSRD model and developed an exact formula for pricing default swaptions.

In contrast to the SSRD model, recent developments in credit derivatives modelling have focused on integrating market dynamics - such as stock prices, volatilities, and default intensities - while making more restrictive assumptions about interest rate. Carr and Linetsky (2006) introduced the jump-to-default constant elasticity of variance (JDCEV) model, a hybrid credit-equity framework where stock prices follow a diffusion process with the potential to drop to zero at default. In this model, interest rate is assumed to be positive and deterministic, and the default intensity is linked to the instantaneous variance of stock price. Di Francesco et al. (2019) extended this model by introducing a stochastic interest rate, which can be negative, using the Vasicek process, relaxing the assumption of positive and deterministic rate. However, these assumptions, particularly around interest rate, may not fully reflect recent market conditions, such as the Bank of Japan's decision to raise rates in March 2024, signaling an end to the era of negative interest rate.

While the SSRD model provides key advantages, it does not offer a closed-form solution for CDS spreads, requiring approximation methods. Brigo and Alfonsi (2005) proposed an analytical approximation using the Vasicek-mapping technique to price CDS within the SSRD framework. This method involves mapping the two-dimensional correlated CIR dynamics to a correlated Vasicek model, then calculating the CDS spread using the Vasicek dynamics. In this work, we avoid the mapping approach and derive an asymptotic approximation for the CDS spread directly within the SSRD model. Recently, Lorig et al. (2017) introduced a unified method for pricing European-style options across various volatility models, building on earlier work of Pagliarani and Pascucci (2012) and Lorig et al. (2015). Their approach uses Taylor's expansions to solve nonlinear PDEs with state-dependent coefficients. We apply their method to derive a second-order asymptotic approximation for CDS spreads, using the CDS pricing framework of Brigo and Alfonsi (2005). Based on this approximation, we propose a new calibration technique that does not assume uncorrelated interest rate and default intensity factors. Through extensive numerical tests with real-world data, we show that our second-order approximation accurately estimates CDS spreads and outperforms the mapping approximation in the SSRD model.

The rest of this paper is organised as follows: Section 2 introduces the operational mechanism of CDS and reviews the SSRD model. Section 3 establishes the notations, and Section 4 outlines the asymptotic approximation technique. Section 5 presents the explicit approximation formulas for the CDS spread and risk-neutral survival probability. Section 6 details the model calibration process, and Section 7 demonstrates the numerical performance of the proposed method in the calibrated model. The appendices A. 1 to A. 3 contain the explicit expression for the second-order approximation formula of CDS spread and additional calibration results.

# 2 Model and assumptions 

A credit default swap (CDS) is a financial derivative that insures against the default risk of a specific entity, called the reference entity. The protection buyer has the right to sell the reference entity's bonds at face value if a default occurs, with the notional principal defining this face value. To maintain this right, the buyer pays premiums to the seller, based on a percentage of the notional principal determined by the CDS spread. The protection seller compensates the buyer upon default, typically paying a percentage of

the notional principal known as the loss-given-default, which equals one minus the recovery rate.
For analytical simplicity, we assume frictionless financial markets with no arbitrage opportunities or dividends. Following Duffie and Singleton (1999), we model an entity's default as an exogenous process that is independent of default-free markets, with no economic or financial indicators predicting its occurrence. This means the default dynamic is entirely governed by the default intensity process. The default intensity at time $t$, symbolised by $\lambda_{t}$, is defined as the instantaneous probability of the default event. We assume that the default intensity is time-dependent, stochastic, and strictly positive at all times, i.e., $\lambda_{t}>0$ for $t \geq 0$.

Assumption 1. The default is hypothesised as the first jump in a Cox process (doubly stochastic Poisson process), and the time $\tau$ at which the default occurs, is characterised as the initial jump time within this framework.

Let us introduce a complete filtered probability space $(\Omega, \mathcal{G}, \mathbb{P})$, where $\mathbb{P}$ denotes the risk-neutral pricing measure based on the short-term interest rate process $r_{t}$. We define the filtration $\mathbb{D}:=\left\{\mathcal{D}_{t}, t \geq 0\right\}$, where $\mathcal{D}_{t}:=\sigma\left(\mathrm{D}_{u} \mid u \leq t\right)$, with a right-continuous process $\mathrm{D}_{t}:=\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau \leq t\}}$, capturing the occurrence and precise timing of a default event. Moreover, we define the filtration $\mathbb{F}:=\left\{\mathcal{F}_{t}, t \geq 0\right\}$, representing the information of the default-free market up to time $t$. Let $\mathbb{G}:=\left\{\mathcal{G}_{t}, t \geq 0\right\}$, be an arbitrary filtration on $(\Omega, \mathcal{G}, \mathbb{P})$, which is assumed to satisfy $\mathbb{G}=\mathbb{F} \vee \mathbb{D}$, i.e., $\mathcal{G}_{t}=\mathcal{F}_{t} \vee \mathcal{D}_{t}$. Therefore, $\mathbb{G}$ is the enlarged filtration. This probability space forms the foundation for all subsequent stochastic processes, with expectations calculated with respect to $\mathbb{P}$.

Definition 1. (Brigo and Mercurio (2001), Section 22.2.3) Let $\Lambda_{t}$ denote the cumulative intensity up to time $t$, which is defined through the formula $\Lambda_{t}:=\int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \mathrm{~d} s$. By the property of the Cox process, the default time is permitted to be denoted as $\tau:=\Lambda^{-1}(\xi)$, where $\xi$ is a standard exponential random variable independent of $\mathcal{F}_{t}$.

Remark 1. Assuming that the default intensity $\lambda_{t}$ indicates the instantaneous probability of default in the infinitesimal interval $[t, t+\mathrm{d} t]$, given no prior default, it can be inferred that

$$
\lambda_{t} \mathrm{~d} t=\mathbb{P}(t \leq \tau<t+\mathrm{d} t \mid \tau \geq t)
$$

Thus, the survival probability at time $t$, under the risk-neutral measure, is given as

$$
\mathbb{P}(\tau \geq t)=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{P}\left(\xi \geq \int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{0}^{t} \lambda_{s} \mathrm{~d} s}\right]
$$

Within the two-dimensional shifted square-root diffusion (SSRD) model proposed by Brigo and Alfonsi (2005), the short-term interest rate $r_{t}$ and the default intensity $\lambda_{t}$ are modelled as correlated Cox-IngersollRoss (CIR) processes. The model dynamics are given as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} r_{t} & =\alpha_{1}\left(\beta_{1}-r_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\sigma_{1} \sqrt{r_{t}} \mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(1)} \\
\mathrm{d} \lambda_{t} & =\alpha_{2}\left(\beta_{2}-\lambda_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\sigma_{2} \sqrt{\lambda_{t}} \mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(2)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathrm{W}_{t}^{(1)}$ and $\mathrm{W}_{t}^{(1)}$ are standard Brownian motions under $\mathbb{P}$, with instantaneous correlation $\rho \in[-1,1]$. That is, $\mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(1)} \mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(2)}=\rho \mathrm{d} t$. To ensure that the interest rate and the default intensity always remain positive, the parameters must satisfy the following Feller conditions

$$
2 \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}>\sigma_{1}^{2}, \quad 2 \alpha_{2} \beta_{2}>\sigma_{2}^{2}
$$

where $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \beta_{1}, \beta_{2}, \sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}$ are constants.
Remark 2. In the SSRD model (2), the formula for the risk-neutral survival probability is analogous to that for the zero-coupon bond ( ZCB ) price. Hence, we have

$$
\mathrm{Q}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \lambda_{s} \mathrm{~d} s}\right]=\mathrm{A}(t, \mathrm{~T}) \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{B}(t, \mathrm{~T}) \lambda_{t}}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{A}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & :=\left(\frac{2 h \mathrm{e}^{\frac{\left(\alpha_{2}+h\right)(\mathrm{T}-t)}{2}}}{2 h+\left(\alpha_{2}+h\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{h(\mathrm{~T}-t)}-1\right)}\right)^{\frac{2 \alpha_{2} \beta_{2}}{\sigma_{2}^{2}}} \\
\mathrm{~B}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & :=\frac{2\left(\mathrm{e}^{h(\mathrm{~T}-t)}-1\right)}{2 h+\left(\alpha_{2}+h\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{h(\mathrm{~T}-t)}-1\right)} \\
h & :=\sqrt{\alpha_{2}^{2}+2 \sigma_{2}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

# 3 CDS spread 

The CDS spread is determined by equating the present value of all expected future premium payments to that of the expected protection payment involved in the CDS.

Proposition 1. Let $t_{i}$ be the i-th premium payment date, and M be the total number of premium payments such that $0 \leq t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{\mathrm{M}}$. Moreover, we denote the maturity as T , typically $t_{\mathrm{M}}=\mathrm{T}$. Thus, the CDS spread at time $t$ is derived as

$$
\mathrm{R}_{t}=\frac{\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}}(1-\zeta) \int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{s}\left(r_{\mathrm{u}}+\lambda_{\mathrm{u}}\right) \mathrm{d} u} \lambda_{s} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \mathrm{d} s}{\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}} \int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{s}\left(r_{\mathrm{u}}+\lambda_{\mathrm{u}}\right) \mathrm{d} u} \lambda_{s} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]\left(s-t_{\mathrm{N}(s)-1}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}} \sum_{i=\mathrm{N}(t)}^{\mathrm{M}}\left(t_{i}-t_{i-1}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{t_{i}}\left(r_{s}+\lambda_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]}
$$

where $t_{\mathrm{N}(t)}$ is the first date among the $t_{i}$ that follows $t$, and $\zeta$ is the recovery rate.
Proof. On the probability space $(\Omega, \mathcal{G}, \mathbb{P})$, assuming a unit notional principal, the discounted value at time $t$ of all expected premium payments based on rate $\mathrm{R}_{t}$ is given as

$$
\operatorname{Pre}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\tau} r_{s} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\tau-t_{\mathrm{N}(\tau)-1}\right) \mathrm{R}_{t} \mathbb{1}_{\{\tau<\mathrm{T}\}}+\sum_{i=\mathrm{N}(t)}^{\mathrm{M}}\left(t_{i}-t_{i-1}\right) \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{t_{i}} r_{s} \mathrm{~d} s} \mathrm{R}_{t} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\tau \geq t_{i}\right\}} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

and that of the expected protection payment is given by

$$
\operatorname{Pro}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}} \mathbb{E}\left[(1-\zeta) \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\tau} r_{s} \mathrm{~d} s} \mathbb{1}_{\{\tau<\mathrm{T}\}} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

By Corollary 5.1.1 and Corollary 5.1.3 in Bielecki and Rutkowski (2004), the above two formulas are transformed into the following form
$\operatorname{Pre}(t, \mathrm{~T})=\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\tau} r_{s} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\tau-t_{\mathrm{N}(\tau)-1}\right) \mathrm{R}_{t} \mathbb{1}_{\{\tau<\mathrm{T}\}} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i=\mathrm{N}(t)}^{\mathrm{M}}\left(t_{i}-t_{i-1}\right) \mathrm{R}_{t} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{t_{i}} r_{s} \mathrm{~d} s} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\tau>t_{i}\right\}} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}} \mathrm{R}_{t}\left(\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{s}\left(r_{u}+\lambda_{u}\right) \mathrm{d} u} \lambda_{s}\left|\mathcal{F}_{t}\right|\left(s-t_{\mathrm{N}(s)-1}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\sum_{i=\mathrm{N}(t)}^{\mathrm{M}}\left(t_{i}-t_{i-1}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{t_{i}}\left(r_{s}+\lambda_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s}\left|\mathcal{F}_{t}\right|\right)\right. \\
\operatorname{Pro}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & =\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\tau} r_{s} \mathrm{~d} s}(1-\zeta) \mathbb{1}_{\{\tau<\mathrm{T}\}} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{1}_{\{\tau>t\}}(1-\zeta) \int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{s}\left(r_{u}+\lambda_{u}\right) \mathrm{d} u} \lambda_{s} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

CDS spread is the rate $\mathrm{R}_{t}$ which makes the value of the premium and protection legs in CDS equal to each other. Thus, from the derivations above, we get the formula for CDS spread in (3).

Remark 3. Market CDS spread at any time can be obtained by setting $t=0$ in (3) and adjusting the remaining time to maturities accordingly. Thus, going forward we use the following spread formula

$$
\mathrm{R} \equiv \mathrm{R}_{0}=\frac{(1-\zeta) \int_{0}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{0}^{s}\left(r_{u}+\lambda_{u}\right) \mathrm{d} u} \lambda_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s}{\int_{0}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{0}^{s}\left(r_{u}+\lambda_{u}\right) \mathrm{d} u} \lambda_{s}\right]\left(s-t_{\mathrm{N}(s)-1}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\sum_{i=1}^{\mathrm{M}}\left(t_{i}-t_{i-1}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{0}^{t_{i}}\left(r_{s}+\lambda_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s}\right]}
$$

Although the SSRD model provides an effective approach for modelling CDS prices, the risk-neutral expectation formula (3) lacks a closed-form solution. Thus, we derive the approximation formulas for it using the approximation method and procedure outlined in Pascucci (2011), Lorig et al. (2015) and Lorig et al. (2017).

# 4 Asymptotic approximation technique 

First, we outline the procedure for approximating the solution to a Cauchy problem, which serves as the foundation for deriving the approximation formula for the CDS spread in (3). Consider a Cauchy problem in the following form

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\partial_{t}+\mathcal{A}(t)\right) u(t, z) & =0, & & t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}), z \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \\
u(\mathrm{~T}, z) & =\varphi(z), & & z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{A}(t)$ is the $d$-dimensional second-order differential operator

$$
\mathcal{A}(t):=\sum_{|\alpha| \leq 2} a_{\alpha}(t, z) \mathrm{D}_{z}^{\alpha}
$$

In the above formula, $\alpha$ is written using the standard multi-index notation and is given as follows

$$
\alpha:=\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{d}\right) \in \mathbb{N}_{0}^{d}, \quad|\alpha|:=\sum_{i=1}^{d} \alpha_{i}
$$

Then, the differential operator $\mathrm{D}_{z}^{\alpha}:=\partial_{z_{1}}^{\alpha_{1}} \cdots \partial_{z_{d}}^{\alpha_{d}}$. We assume that the coefficients $a_{\alpha}$ are bounded and have globally Lipschitz continuous derivatives up to order $\mathrm{N} \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$, with the derivatives having a bounded norm. Moreover, we denote by $\left(a_{\alpha, n}(t, z)\right)_{0 \leq n \leq \mathrm{N}}$ an N -th order polynomial expansion for any $t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}]$, where $a_{\alpha, n}(t, z)$ are polynomials with state-independent $a_{\alpha, 0}$, i.e, $a_{\alpha, 0}(t, \cdot)=a_{\alpha, 0}(t)$. For any fixed

$\bar{z}: \mathbb{R}^{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d}$, we define $a_{\alpha, n}$ as the $n$-th order term of the Taylor expansion of $a_{\alpha}$ in the spatial variables around $\bar{z}(\cdot)$. That is, we set

$$
a_{\alpha, n}(\cdot, z):=\sum_{|\beta|=n} \frac{\mathrm{D}_{z}^{\beta} a_{\alpha}(\cdot, \bar{z}(\cdot))}{\beta!}(z-\bar{z}(\cdot))^{\beta}, \quad n \leq \mathrm{N}, \quad|\alpha| \leq 2
$$

with $\beta!:=\beta_{1}!\cdots \beta_{d}$ ! and $z^{\beta}:=z_{1}^{\beta_{1}} \cdots z_{d}^{\beta_{d}}$. The above expansion for the coefficients $a_{\alpha}$ allows the expansion point $\bar{z}$ to evolve in time, which enhances the approximation accuracy for option prices, as noted in Lorig et al. (2017). Let us assume that $\mathcal{A}(t)$ can be rewritten as $\mathcal{A}(t)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \mathcal{A}_{n}(t)$, where $\mathcal{A}_{n}(t)$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{A}_{n}(t):=\sum_{|\alpha| \leq 2} a_{\alpha, n}(t, z) \mathrm{D}_{z}^{\alpha}
$$

In light of this expansion, we express $u$ as an infinite sum

$$
u(t, z)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} u_{n}(t, z)
$$

Inserting the above formulas - expanded forms of $\mathcal{A}$ and $u$ into (5) - we find that $\left(u_{n}(t, z)\right)_{n \geq 0}$ satisfy the following sequence of Cauchy problems

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\left(\partial_{t}+\mathcal{A}_{0}(t)\right) u_{0}(t, z)=0, & u_{0}(\mathrm{~T}, z)=\varphi(z), & z \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \\
\left(\partial_{t}+\mathcal{A}_{0}(t)\right) u_{n}(t, z)=-\sum_{h=1}^{\infty} \mathcal{A}_{k}(t) u_{n-h}(t, z), & u_{n}(\mathrm{~T}, z)=0, & z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
\end{array}
$$

Since functions $a_{\alpha, 0}(t, \cdot)$ depend only on $t$, the operator $\mathcal{A}_{0}(t)$ is elliptic with time-dependent coefficients. It is useful to express $\mathcal{A}_{0}(t)$ in the following form

$$
\mathcal{A}_{0}(t)=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{d} \mathrm{C}_{i, j}(t) \partial_{z_{i} z_{j}}+\sum_{i=1}^{d} m_{i}(t) \partial_{z_{i}}+\gamma(t)
$$

where $\mathrm{C}(t)=\left(\mathrm{C}_{i, j}\right)_{1 \leq i, j \leq d}(t)$, is a positive definite $d \times d$ matrix, $m(t)=\left(m_{i}\right)_{1 \leq i \leq d}(t)$, is a $d$-dimensional vector, and $\gamma(t)$ is a scalar function. By Duhamel's principle, we can derive $u_{0}(t, z)$, the solution to (7), as follows

$$
u_{0}(t, z)=\mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \gamma(s) \mathrm{d} s} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathrm{~d} \eta \Gamma_{0}(t, z, \mathrm{~T}, \eta) \varphi(\eta)
$$

where $\Gamma_{0}$ is identified as a $d$-dimensional Gaussian density function

$$
\Gamma_{0}(t, z, \mathrm{~T}, \eta):=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(2 \pi)^{d}|\mathbf{C}(t, \mathrm{~T})|}} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2}(\eta-z-\mathbf{m}(t, \mathrm{~T}))^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{C}(t, \mathrm{~T})^{-1}(\eta-z-\mathbf{m}(t, \mathrm{~T}))\right)
$$

with covariance matrix $\mathbf{C}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ and mean vector $z+\mathbf{m}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ defined as

$$
\mathbf{C}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{C}(s) \mathrm{d} s, \quad \mathbf{m}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} m(s) \mathrm{d} s
$$

Theorem 1. For any $n \geq 1$, the function $u_{n}(t, z)$ satisfying (8), is given explicitly by

$$
u_{n}(t, z)=\mathcal{L}_{n}(t, \mathrm{~T}) u_{0}(t, z), \quad t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}), z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

where $\mathcal{L}_{n}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ is defined as

$$
\mathcal{L}_{n}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\sum_{h=1}^{n} \int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{1} \int_{s_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{2} \cdots \int_{s_{h-1}}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{h} \sum_{i \in \mathrm{I}_{n, h}} \mathcal{G}_{i_{1}}\left(t, s_{1}\right) \mathcal{G}_{i_{2}}\left(t, s_{2}\right) \cdots \mathcal{G}_{i_{h}}\left(t, s_{h}\right)
$$

In the above,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{I}_{n, h} & :=\left\{i=\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, \ldots, i_{h}\right) \in \mathbb{N}^{h} \mid i_{1}+i_{2}+\cdots+i_{h}=n\right\}, \quad 1 \leq h \leq n \\
\mathcal{G}_{i}(t, s) & :=\sum_{|\alpha| \leq 2} a_{\alpha, i}(s, \mathcal{M}(t, s)) \mathrm{D}_{z}^{\alpha}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $a_{\alpha, n}$ as specified in (6) and

$$
\mathcal{M}(t, s):=z+\mathbf{m}(t, s)+\mathbf{C}(t, s) \nabla_{z}
$$

We refer the reader to Theorem 3.2 of Lorig et al. (2015) for a proof of the above result.
Remark 4. Under some general assumptions (see Lorig et al. (2015)) on operator $\mathcal{A}(t)$, the following bound for the approximation error holds

$$
\left|u(t, z)-\bar{u}_{\mathrm{N}}(t, z)\right| \leq \mathrm{C}(\mathrm{~T}-t)^{\frac{\mathrm{N}}{2}+1}, \quad t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}), z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

where C is a positive constant that only depends on N , and $\bar{u}_{\mathrm{N}}(t, z)$ is the N -th order approximation, given as

$$
\bar{u}_{\mathrm{N}}(t, z):=\sum_{n=0}^{\mathrm{N}} u_{n}(t, z)
$$

# 5 Approximation formula 

Going back to the CDS spread approximation problem discussed in Section 3, we notice that the following terms in (3) lack a closed-form solution under the SSRD model

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}}\left(r_{s}+\lambda_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right], \quad \mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}}\left(r_{s}+\lambda_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s} \lambda_{\mathrm{T}} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]
$$

This is due to the fact that in the SSRD model, the short-term interest rate $r_{t}$ and default intensity $\lambda_{t}$ are assumed to follow correlated CIR processes. In order to get around this hurdle of unavailable closed-form solutions for the above two terms, Brigo and Alfonsi (2005) approximated the distribution of correlated CIR processes using correlated Vasicek processes, a technique we call the Vasicek-mapping technique. However, the above two terms also satisfy parabolic Cauchy problems of the type (5). Thus, we can employ the asymptotic approximation technique in Lorig et al. (2015) to derive their higherorder approximations, which can potentially be more accurate than their corresponding approximations obtained from the Vasicek-mapping technique.

To facilitate the analysis, we introduce functions $v(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$ and $h(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$, which are defined as follows

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
v(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}}\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{1} s} x_{\mathrm{s}}+\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{2} s} y_{\mathrm{s}}\right) \mathrm{d} s} \mid x_{t}=x, y_{t}=y\right], & t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}] \\
h(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}}\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{1} s} x_{\mathrm{s}}+\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{2} s} y_{\mathrm{s}}\right) \mathrm{d} s} y_{\mathrm{T}} \mid x_{t}=x, y_{t}=y\right], & t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}]
\end{array}
$$

with the transformations

$$
x_{t}:=\mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{1} t} r_{t}, \quad y_{t}:=\mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{2} t} \lambda_{t}
$$

Therefore, the SSRD model (2) is transformed to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} x_{t} & =\alpha_{1} \beta_{1} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{1} t} \mathrm{~d} t+\sigma_{1} \sqrt{\mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{1} t} x_{t}} \mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(1)} \\
\mathrm{d} y_{t} & =\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{2} t} \mathrm{~d} t+\sigma_{2} \sqrt{\mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{2} t} y_{t}} \mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(2)} \\
\mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(1)} \mathrm{dW}_{t}^{(2)} & =\rho \mathrm{d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

According to the Feynman-Kac principle, (13) and (14) are the solutions to the following Cauchy problems, respectively,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}

# 6 Calibration approach 

For estimating the market CDS spread using our approximation formula (18), we first need to calibrate the parameters in the transformed SSRD model (16) to the market data. Our proposed calibration procedure involves the following three steps:

- Step 1: Calibration of the interest rate model.

We calibrate the parameters of the interest rate process $r_{t}$ in the SSRD model (2) separately to the ZCB prices generated from the interest rate swap curve, such as the London interbank offered rate (LIBOR) swap curve. Since $r_{t}$ follows a CIR process, the ZCB price formula is similar to the one stated in Remark 2, which is given as

$$
\mathrm{P}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} r_{s} \mathrm{~d} s}\right]=\widehat{\mathrm{A}}(t, \mathrm{~T}) \mathrm{e}^{-\widehat{\mathrm{B}}(t, \mathrm{~T}) r_{t}}, \quad t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}]
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\mathrm{A}}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & :=\left(\frac{2 \widehat{h} \mathrm{e}^{\frac{\left(\alpha_{1}+\widehat{h}\right)(\mathrm{T}-t)}{2}}}{2 \widehat{h}+\left(\alpha_{1}+\widehat{h}\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{\widehat{h}(\mathrm{~T}-t)}-1\right)}\right)^{\frac{2 \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}}{\sigma_{1}^{2}}} \\
\widehat{\mathrm{~B}}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & :=\frac{2\left(\mathrm{e}^{\widehat{h}(\mathrm{~T}-t)}-1\right)}{2 \widehat{h}+\left(\alpha_{1}+\widehat{h}\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{\widehat{h}(\mathrm{~T}-t)}-1\right)} \\
\widehat{h} & :=\sqrt{\alpha_{1}^{2}+2 \sigma_{1}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

This calibration step can be formulated as an optimisation problem where the aim is to minimise the difference between the model given prices and the market data. We employ the unweighted nonlinear least squares method, for which the objective function is formalised as follows

$$
\min _{\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \sigma_{1}\right)} \mathrm{F}\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \sigma_{1}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{mkt}}}\left|\mathrm{P}\left(0, \mathrm{~T}_{i}\right)-\widehat{\mathrm{P}}_{i}\right|^{2}, \text { s.t. } \alpha_{1}, \sigma_{1}>0,2 \alpha_{1} \beta_{1}>\sigma_{1}^{2}
$$

Here, $\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{mkt}}$ is the number of ZCB prices from the market and $\widehat{\mathrm{P}}_{i}$ is the market ZCB price observed with maturity $\mathrm{T}_{i}$. We use the Nelder-Mead method for solving the above optimisation problem. After completing this step, we obtain the calibrated values for parameters $\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}$ and $\sigma_{1} . r_{0}$ is observed directly from the market.

- Step 2: Matching the model ZCB price with its approximation.

Since we use the transformed SSRD model (16) to generate the approximation formula for the CDS spread, we need to ensure that the ZCB prices derived from the models for $r_{t}$ and $x_{t}$ are consistent. This is an important calibration step, as it ensures the accuracy of our approximation formula for CDS spreads. Recall that in the transformed SSRD model, interest rate $r_{t}$ is transformed into $\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{1} t} x_{t}$. According to Proposition 3, we can express the ZCB price in terms of $x_{t}$, with $\bar{x}_{\text {fixed }}=x$, as follows

$$
\widehat{\mathrm{P}}(t, x, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{1} s} x_{s} \mathrm{~d} s} \mid x_{t}=x\right]=\widehat{\mathrm{P}}_{0}(t, y, \mathrm{~T})+\widehat{\mathrm{P}}_{1}(t, y, \mathrm{~T}), \quad t \in[0, \mathrm{~T}]
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}_{0}(t, x, \mathrm{~T}) & =\mathrm{e}^{-x \psi\left(-\alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)-\alpha_{1} \beta_{1} \Theta\left(-\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)} \\
\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}_{1}(t, x, \mathrm{~T}) & =\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}_{0}(t, x, \mathrm{~T}) \sigma_{1}^{2} \psi\left(-\alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{1} s}\left(x \psi\left(\alpha_{1}, t, s\right)+\alpha_{1} \beta_{1} \Theta\left(\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, t, s\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& +\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}_{0}(t, x, \mathrm{~T}) \sigma_{1}^{4} \psi\left(-\alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)^{3} \int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{1} s}\left(x \psi\left(\alpha_{1}, t, s\right)+\alpha_{1} \beta_{1} \Theta\left(\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, t, s\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

To maintain consistency in the ZCB prices across the two representations, we introduce a volatility parameter $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ such that

$$
\mathrm{P}(0, \mathrm{~T})^{\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \sigma_{1}\right)}=\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}\left(0, x_{0}, \mathrm{~T}\right)^{\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \widetilde{\sigma}_{1}\right)}
$$

In the above, $\mathrm{P}(0, \mathrm{~T})^{\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \sigma_{1}\right)}$ is the ZCB price generated from the original SSRD model (2), while $\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}\left(0, x_{0}, \mathrm{~T}\right)^{\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \widetilde{\sigma}_{1}\right)}$ is the ZCB price generated the transformed SSRD model (2) with volatility parameter $\sigma_{1}$ being replaced with $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$. This step is similar to the "particular Vasicek volatility" calculation in Brigo and Alfonsi (2005, Page 16). Given that volatility is a positive constant, in the above equation we can replace $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}^{2}$ with $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ instead and solve a quadratic equation in $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$. If the quadratic equation does have solutions, we select the positive square root of the smaller positive $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ as the volatility parameter $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$. However, if the quadratic equation does not have a real solution, we choose the value of $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ that minimises the difference between $\mathrm{P}(0, \mathrm{~T})^{\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \sigma_{1}\right)}$ and $\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}\left(0, x_{0}, \mathrm{~T}\right)^{\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \widetilde{\sigma}_{1}\right)}$ as the particular volatility. From a practical viewpoint, the volatility parameter $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ can be interpreted as the time-averaged value of $\sigma_{1} \sqrt{r_{t}}$ over the interval $[0, \mathrm{~T}]$. We only compute and utilise the volatility parameter $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ corresponding to the longest maturity in the CDS spread dataset. For instance, if we use a CDS spread dataset covering maturities from 1 year to 10 years for the final calibration, we calculate and apply $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ for the 10-year term using (25). In the following calibration steps, we employ $\widetilde{\sigma}_{1}$ as the volatility parameter for the interest rate model, instead of $\sigma_{1}$ obtained in the first step.

- Step 3: Final calibration.

In this step, we calibrate the parameters $\Xi:=\left(\alpha_{2}, \beta_{2}, \sigma_{2}, \lambda_{0}, \rho\right)$ in the transformed SSRD model (16) to the market data on CDS spread using the first-order approximation formula in (18). Using the first-order approximation formula ensures that this step is computationally quick. Moreover, we observe that no loss of precision occurred even when calculating the final estimate using a secondorder approximation formula. In this step, we employ a weighted nonlinear least squares method to minimise the difference between the market CDS spreads and the model CDS spreads, where the weights are chosen to account for different levels of reliability or variability in the market data. The objective function is given as

$$
\min _{\Xi} \mathrm{F}(\Xi)=\sum_{i=1}^{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{mkt}}} \omega_{i}\left|\mathrm{R}_{i}-\widehat{\mathrm{R}}_{i}\right|^{2}, \text { s.t. } \alpha_{2}, \sigma_{2}, \lambda_{0}>0,-1 \leq \rho \leq 1
$$

where $\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{mkt}}$ denotes the number of market CDS spread values used, $\omega_{i}$ denotes the weight of each term, $\mathrm{R}_{i}$ denotes the model CDS spread with maturity $\mathrm{T}_{i}$, and $\widehat{\mathrm{R}}_{i}$ denotes the market CDS spread observed with maturity $\mathrm{T}_{i}$. In the case where we assume $\rho=0$, the objective function simplifies to

$$
\min _{\Xi} \mathrm{F}(\widehat{\Xi})=\sum_{i=1}^{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{mkt}}} \omega_{i}\left|\mathrm{R}_{i}-\widehat{\mathrm{R}}_{i}\right|^{2}, \text { s.t. } \alpha_{2}, \sigma_{2}, \lambda_{0}>0
$$

When presenting the numerical results in Section 7, we specify the choice of weights depending on the available data.

After obtaining all the parameter estimates from the calibration procedure, we compute the estimate for the CDS spread using (4) with $\mathrm{N}=2$. We also compute the estimate of the risk-neutral survival probability $\widehat{\mathrm{Q}}$ by using (22) and compare it with the survival probability $\widehat{\mathrm{Q}}$ inferred from the market CDS spreads. Let $\widehat{\mathrm{Q}}_{i}$ denote the survival probability up to time $\mathrm{T}_{i}$. Then, we have the following bootstrapping formula for the market survival probability

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{j} \widehat{\mathrm{R}}_{i}\left(\mathrm{~T}_{i}-\mathrm{T}_{i-1}\right) \widehat{\mathrm{Q}}_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{j}(1-\zeta)\left(\widehat{\mathrm{Q}}_{i}-\widehat{\mathrm{Q}}_{i-1}\right), \quad 1 \leq j \leq \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{mkt}}
$$

where $\widehat{\mathrm{R}}_{i}$ denotes the market CDS spread observed with maturity $\mathrm{T}_{i}$.

# 8 Conclusion 

In this work, we provide a closed-form approximation formula for the CDS spread under the SSRD model framework. Specifically, we utilise Taylor's theorem to derive approximations for the two crucial

components within the general CDS spread formula, which are solutions to Cauchy problems. Most notably, we derive our approximation without assuming uncorrelated interest rate and default intensity, as required by Brigo and Alfonsi (2005) for their calibration procedure. With several numerical studies using different market data on CDS spread, we demonstrate the efficiency of our calibration procedure and accuracy of our CDS spread approximation, while comparing it with other existing approximations.

## Appendix
## A. 1 The approximation formula

Within the framework established in Section 2, 4 and 5, we derive the the N-th order approximation formula for CDS spread at time 0 , as given in (18). However, we restrict the display of the explicit expression for the approximation formula to the second order, as various numerical experiments indicate that the second-order approximation is sufficiently accurate.

From Proposition 2, we obtain the second-order approximation formula of CDS spread at $t=0$, given

by

$$
\mathrm{R}_{2}=\frac{(1-\zeta) \int_{0}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{2} s} \sum_{n=0}^{2} h_{n}(0, x, y, s) \mathrm{d} s}{\int_{0}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{2} s} \sum_{n=0}^{2} h_{n}(0, x, y, s)\left(s-\iota_{\mathrm{N}(s)-1}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\sum_{i=1}^{\mathrm{M}}\left(t_{i}-t_{i-1}\right) \sum_{n=0}^{2} v_{n}\left(0, x, y, t_{i}\right)}
$$

with the zeroth term $v_{0}$ and $h_{0}$ specified in (20) and (21), respectively. To simplify the derivation process, we introduce the following useful functions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Psi_{0}\left(\alpha, i, j, t_{1}, t_{2}\right) & :=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathrm{~d} s \\
\Psi_{1}\left(\alpha, i, j, k, t_{1}, t_{2}\right) & :=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{C}_{1,1}(t, s)^{k} \mathrm{~d} s \\
\Psi_{2}\left(\alpha, i, j, k, t_{1}, t_{2}\right) & :=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{C}_{2,2}(t, s)^{k} \mathrm{~d} s \\
\Psi_{3}\left(\alpha, i, j, k, t_{1}, t_{2}\right) & :=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{C}_{1,2}(t, s)^{k} \mathrm{~d} s \\
& =\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{C}_{2,1}(t, s)^{k} \mathrm{~d} s \\
\Phi_{1}\left(\alpha, i, j, t_{1}, t_{2}\right) & :=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{C}_{1,1}(t, s) \mathbf{C}_{1,2}(t, s) \mathrm{d} s \\
\Phi_{2}\left(\alpha, i, j, t_{1}, t_{2}\right) & :=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{C}_{2,2}(t, s) \mathbf{C}_{1,2}(t, s) \mathrm{d} s \\
\Phi_{3}\left(\alpha, i, j, t_{1}, t_{2}\right) & :=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha s} \bar{x}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}(t, s)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{C}_{1,1}(t, s) \mathbf{C}_{2,2}(t, s) \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

for any $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}, i, j, k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$, and $t \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2} \leq \mathrm{T}$, where $\bar{x}$ and $\bar{y}$ are as defined in (19). Moreover, for all coefficient functions in the operator $\mathcal{A}(t)$ in (17), we set, taking $a(t, x, y)$ as an example,

$$
a_{i, j}(t):=\partial_{x}^{i} \partial_{y}^{j} a(t, \bar{x}, \bar{y}), \quad i, j \in \mathbb{N}_{0}
$$

Thus, the zeroth order term of the expansion for $\mathcal{A}(t)$ in (17) can be rewritten as follows

$$
\mathcal{A}_{0}(s)=a_{0,0}(s) \partial_{x x}+b_{0,0}(s) \partial_{y y}+c_{0,0}(s) \partial_{x y}+\kappa_{0,0}(s) \partial_{x}+k_{0,0}(s) \partial_{y}+\gamma_{0,0}(s)
$$

where

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
a_{0,0}(s)=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{1}^{2} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{1} s} \bar{x}(s), & \kappa_{0,0}(s)=\alpha_{1} \beta_{1} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{1} s}, & c_{0,0}(s)=\widehat{\rho} \bar{x}^{\frac{1}{2}} \bar{y}^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathrm{e}^{\bar{\alpha} s} \\
b_{0,0}(s)=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{2}^{2} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{2} s} \bar{y}(s), & k_{0,0}(s)=\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{2} s}, & \gamma_{0,0}(s)=-\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{1} t} \bar{x}(s)+\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{2} t} \bar{y}(s)\right)
\end{array}
$$

with

$$
\widehat{\rho}:=\rho \sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}, \quad \bar{\alpha}:=\frac{\alpha_{1}+\alpha_{2}}{2}
$$

Applying (10) and (11), we get the covariance matrix $\mathbf{C}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ and the mean vector $z+\mathbf{m}(t, \mathrm{~T})$, expressed as follows

$$
\mathbf{C}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
\mathbf{C}_{1,1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & \mathbf{C}_{1,2}(t, \mathrm{~T}) \\
\mathbf{C}_{2,1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & \mathbf{C}_{2,2}(t, \mathrm{~T})
\end{array}\right), \quad \mathbf{m}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\binom{\alpha_{1} \beta_{1} \psi\left(\alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)}{\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \psi\left(\alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)}
$$

where the elements of $\mathbf{C}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{C}_{1,1}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\sigma_{1}^{2}\left(\bar{x}_{\text {fixed }} \psi\left(\alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)+\alpha_{1} \beta_{1} \Theta\left(\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)\right) \\
& \mathbf{C}_{2,2}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\sigma_{2}^{2}\left(\widetilde{y}_{\text {fixed }} \psi\left(\alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)+\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \Theta\left(\alpha_{2}, \alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)\right) \\
& \mathbf{C}_{1,2}(t, \mathrm{~T})=\mathbf{C}_{2,1}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\mathbf{C}_{2,1}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\widehat{\rho} \Psi_{0}(\bar{\alpha}, 1,1, t, \mathrm{~T})
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 1 yields the first term $v_{1}$, for $t \in[0, \mathrm{~T})$, as follows

$$
v_{1}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})=\mathcal{L}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) \mathrm{u}_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})=\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{1} \mathcal{G}_{1}\left(t, s_{1}\right) \mathrm{u}_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{G}_{1}(t, s)=\mathcal{A}_{1}(s, \mathcal{M}(t, s))
$$

with

$$
\mathcal{M}(t, s)=\binom{\mathcal{M}_{1}(t, s)}{\mathcal{M}_{2}(t, s)}:=\binom{x+\alpha_{x} \beta_{x} \psi\left(\alpha_{x}, t, s\right)+\mathbf{C}_{1,1}(t, s) \partial_{x}+\mathbf{C}_{1,2}(t, s) \partial_{y}}{y+\alpha_{y} \beta_{y} \psi\left(\alpha_{y}, t, s\right)+\mathbf{C}_{2,2}(t, s) \partial_{y}+\mathbf{C}_{2,1}(t, s) \partial_{x}}
$$

Inserting (A.1.3) into (A.1.2), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{G}_{1}(t, s) & =\left(\mathcal{M}_{1}(t, s)-\bar{x}(t, s)\right) \mathcal{A}_{1,0}(s)+\left(\mathcal{M}_{2}(t, s)-\bar{y}(t, s)\right) \mathcal{A}_{0,1}(s) \\
& =\widetilde{x}(t, s) \mathcal{A}_{1,0}(s)+\widetilde{y}(t, s) \mathcal{A}_{0,1}(s)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\widetilde{x}$ and $\widetilde{y}$ are defined as follows

$$
\widetilde{x}(t, s):=\mathbf{C}_{1,1}(t, s) \partial_{x}+\mathbf{C}_{1,2}(t, s) \partial_{y}, \quad \widetilde{y}(t, s):=\mathbf{C}_{2,2}(t, s) \partial_{y}+\mathbf{C}_{2,1}(t, s) \partial_{x}
$$

and $\mathcal{A}_{1,0}(s)$ and $\mathcal{A}_{0,1}(s)$ are components of the first order term of $\mathcal{A}(t)$ expansion. Specifically, $\mathcal{A}_{1}(s)=$ $\mathcal{A}_{1,0}(s)+\mathcal{A}_{0,1}(s)$, where each term is defined as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{A}_{1,0}(s):=a_{1,0}(s) \partial_{x x}+c_{1,0}(s) \partial_{x y}+\gamma_{1,0}(s) \\
& \mathcal{A}_{0,1}(s):=b_{0,1}(s) \partial_{y y}+c_{0,1}(s) \partial_{x y}+\gamma_{0,1}(s)
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
a_{1,0}(1)=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{1}^{2} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{1} s}, & c_{1,0}(s)=\frac{1}{2} \widehat{\rho} \bar{x}^{-\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \bar{y}^{\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \mathrm{e}^{\bar{\alpha} s}, & \gamma_{1,0}(s)=-\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{1} s} \\
b_{0,1}(s)=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{2}^{2} \mathrm{e}^{\alpha_{2} s}, & c_{0,1}(s)=\frac{1}{2} \widehat{\rho} \bar{x}^{\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \bar{y}^{-\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \mathrm{e}^{\bar{\alpha} s}, & \gamma_{0,1}(s)=-\mathrm{e}^{-\alpha_{2} s}
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the explicit expression of $\mathcal{L}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{L}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T})=\sum_{i=1}^{6} \mathrm{~L}_{1,0}^{(i)}(t, \mathrm{~T})+\sum_{i=1}^{6} \mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(i)}(t, \mathrm{~T})
$$

where each component is defined as follows

$$
\mathrm{L}_{1,0}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{1}^{2} \Psi_{1}\left(\alpha_{1}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x}^{3}, \quad \mathrm{~L}_{1,0}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{1}^{2} \Psi_{3}\left(\alpha_{1}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathrm{L}_{1,0}^{(3)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \widehat{\rho} \Psi_{1}(\bar{\alpha},-1,1,1, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y}, & \mathrm{~L}_{1,0}^{(4)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \widehat{\rho} \Psi_{3}\left(\bar{\alpha},-1,1,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x} \partial_{y}^{2} \\
\mathrm{~L}_{1,0}^{(5)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=-\Psi_{1}\left(-\alpha_{1}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x}, & \mathrm{~L}_{1,0}^{(6)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=-\Psi_{3}\left(-\alpha_{1}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{y}
\end{array}
$$

and

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathrm{L}_{0,1}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{2}^{2} \Psi_{2}\left(\alpha_{2}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{y}^{3}, & \mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{2}^{2} \Psi_{3}\left(\alpha_{2}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x} \partial_{y}^{2} \\
\mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(3)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \widehat{\rho} \Psi_{2}\left(\bar{\alpha}, 1,-1,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x} \partial_{y}^{2}, & \mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(4)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{2} \widehat{\rho} \Psi_{3}\left(\bar{\alpha}, 1,-1,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y} \\
\mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(5)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=-\Psi_{2}\left(-\alpha_{2}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{y}, & \mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(6)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=-\Psi_{3}\left(-\alpha_{2}, 0,0,1, t, \mathrm{~T}\right) \partial_{x}
\end{array}
$$

We observe that the partial derivatives of $v_{0}$ in (20) exhibit the property such that

$$
\partial_{x}^{i} \partial_{y}^{j} v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})=(-1)^{i+j} \psi\left(-\alpha_{1}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)^{i} \psi\left(-\alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)^{j} v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T}), \quad i, j \in \mathbb{N}_{0}
$$

Multiplying (20) and (A.1.4) in accordance with the principle outlined in (A.1.5), we derive the explicit expression for $v_{1}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$. Analogous to (A.1.1), the second term in the approximation of $v(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$, for any $t \in[0, \mathrm{~T})$, is given as

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{2}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T}) & =\mathcal{L}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T}) \\
& =\left(\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{1} \mathcal{G}_{2}\left(t, s_{1}\right)+\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{1} \mathcal{G}_{1}\left(t, s_{1}\right) \int_{s_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{2} \mathcal{G}_{1}\left(t, s_{2}\right)\right) v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{G}_{1}(t, s)$ is as specified in (A.1.2), and $\mathcal{G}_{2}(t, s)$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{G}_{2}(t, s)=\frac{1}{2} \widetilde{x}(t, s)^{2} \mathcal{A}_{2,0}(s)+\widetilde{x}(t, s) \widetilde{y}(t, s) \mathcal{A}_{1,1}(s)+\widetilde{y}(t, s)^{2} \mathcal{A}_{0,2}(s)
$$

Here, $\mathcal{A}_{2,0}(s), \mathcal{A}_{1,1}(s)$, and $\mathcal{A}_{0,2}(s)$ are components of $\mathcal{A}_{2}(s)$, which are defined as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{A}_{2,0}(s) & :=-\frac{1}{4} \widehat{\rho} \bar{x}^{-\frac{3}{2}}(t, s) \bar{y}^{\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \mathrm{e}^{\bar{\alpha} t} \partial_{x y} \\
\mathcal{A}_{1,1}(s) & :=\frac{1}{4} \widehat{\rho} \bar{x}^{-\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \bar{y}^{-\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \mathrm{e}^{\bar{\alpha} t} \partial_{x y} \\
\mathcal{A}_{0,2}(s) & :=-\frac{1}{4} \widehat{\rho} \bar{x}^{\frac{1}{2}}(t, s) \bar{y}^{-\frac{3}{2}}(t, s) \mathrm{e}^{\bar{\alpha} t} \partial_{x y}
\end{aligned}
$$

Accordingly, we divide the operator $\mathcal{L}_{2}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ into two parts, such that $\mathcal{L}_{2}(t, \mathrm{~T})=\mathcal{L}_{2}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T})+\mathcal{L}_{2}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T})$. We define the first component as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}_{2}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & :=\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{1} \mathcal{G}_{2}\left(t, s_{1}\right) \\
& =\widehat{\rho}\left(-\frac{1}{8} \sum_{i=1}^{3} \mathrm{~L}_{2,0}^{(i)}(t, \mathrm{~T})+\frac{1}{4} \sum_{i=1}^{4} \mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(i)}(t, \mathrm{~T})-\frac{1}{8} \sum_{i=1}^{3} \mathrm{~L}_{0,2}^{(i)}(t, \mathrm{~T})\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where each term is derived in the following form

$$
\mathrm{L}_{2,0}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\Psi_{1}(\bar{\alpha},-3,1,2, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{3} \partial_{y}, \quad \mathrm{~L}_{2,0}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\Psi_{3}(\bar{\alpha},-3,1,2, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x} \partial_{y}^{3}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathrm{L}_{2,0}^{(3)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=2 \Phi_{1}(\bar{\alpha},-3,1, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y}^{2}, & \mathrm{~L}_{0,2}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\Psi_{2}(\bar{\alpha}, 1,-3,2, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x} \partial_{y}^{3} \\
\mathrm{~L}_{0,2}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=2 \Phi_{2}(\bar{\alpha}, 1,-3, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y}^{2}, & \mathrm{~L}_{0,2}^{(3)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=2 \Phi_{2}(\bar{\alpha}, 1,-3, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y}^{2} \\
\mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\Phi_{3}(\bar{\alpha},-1,-1, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y}^{2}, & \mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\Phi_{1}(\bar{\alpha},-1,-1, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{3} \partial_{y} \\
\mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(3)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\Phi_{2}(\bar{\alpha},-1,-1, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x} \partial_{y}^{3}, & \mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(4)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\Psi_{3}(\bar{\alpha},-1,-1,2, t, \mathrm{~T}) \partial_{x}^{2} \partial_{y}^{2}
\end{array}
$$

The second part is characterised by

$$
\mathcal{L}_{2}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{1} \mathcal{G}_{1}\left(t, s_{1}\right) \int_{s_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{2} \mathcal{G}_{1}\left(t, s_{2}\right)=\int_{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{~d} s_{1} \mathcal{G}_{1}\left(t, s_{1}\right) \mathcal{L}_{1}\left(s_{1}, \mathrm{~T}\right)
$$

We will not provide an explicit result for the above integral, as the integrand consists of multiple components, and numerical computation is considered more efficient. By summing (20), (A.1.1) and (A.1.6), we obtain the second-order approximation of $v(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$, which also represents the second-order approximation of $\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{0}^{\mathrm{T}}\left(\tau_{s}+\lambda_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s}\right]$.

The second-order approximation of $h(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$ is derived in a similar way but includes additional terms compared to the second-order approximation of $v(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$. Given the zeroth term $h_{0}$ in (21), the first term $h_{1}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$ is given by

$$
h_{1}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})=\mathcal{L}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) h_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})=\mathcal{L}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T})\left(v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})\left(y+\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \psi\left(\alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)\right)\right)
$$

Let $f: \mathbb{R}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be an infinitely differentiable function. The following property holds

$$
\partial_{x}^{i} \partial_{y}^{j}(f \cdot y)=\left(\partial_{x}^{i} \partial_{y}^{j} f\right) \cdot y+j \cdot\left(\partial_{x}^{i} \partial_{y}^{j-1} f\right), \quad i, j \in \mathbb{N}_{0}
$$

Thus, $h_{1}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$ can be rewritten as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
h_{1}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T}) & =\left(\mathcal{L}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})\right)\left(y+\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \psi\left(\alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)\right)+\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T}) \\
& =v_{1}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})\left(y+\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \psi\left(\alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)\right)+\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T}) v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ denotes the operator for the second term on the right-hand side of (A.1.9), which is expressed as

$$
\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{1}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\frac{1}{\partial_{y}}\left(\mathrm{~L}_{1,0}^{(2)}+\mathrm{L}_{1,0}^{(3)}+2 \mathrm{~L}_{1,0}^{(4)}+\mathrm{L}_{1,0}^{(2)}+3 \mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(1)}+2 \mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(2)}+2 \mathrm{~L}_{0,1}^{(3)}+\mathrm{L}_{0,1}^{(4)}+\mathrm{L}_{0,1}^{(5)}\right)(t, \mathrm{~T})
$$

Analogously, the second term in the approximation for $h(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$ is deduced as follows

$$
h_{2}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})=v_{2}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})\left(y+\alpha_{2} \beta_{2} \psi\left(\alpha_{2}, t, \mathrm{~T}\right)\right)+\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}(t, \mathrm{~T}) v_{0}(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})
$$

We divide the operator $\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ for the source term into two parts, such that $\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}(t, \mathrm{~T}):=\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T})+$ $\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T})$. The first component denotes the operator of the extra terms derived from (A.1.7) according to the principle in (A.1.9), and the second component denotes that derived from (A.1.8). Therefore, $\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T})$ is given as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}^{(1)}(t, \mathrm{~T}) & :=\frac{1}{\partial_{y}}\left(\mathrm{~L}_{2,0}^{(1)}+3 \mathrm{~L}_{2,0}^{(2)}+2 \mathrm{~L}_{2,0}^{(3)}+3 \mathrm{~L}_{0,2}^{(1)}+\mathrm{L}_{0,2}^{(2)}+2 \mathrm{~L}_{0,2}^{(3)}\right)(t, \mathrm{~T}) \\
& +\frac{1}{\partial_{y}}\left(2 \mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(1)}+\mathrm{L}_{1,1}^{(2)}+3 \mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(3)}+2 \mathrm{~L}_{1,1}^{(4)}\right)(t, \mathrm{~T})
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{2}^{(2)}(t, \mathrm{~T})$, we do not present the explicit formula either. By summing (21), (A.1.10) and (A.1.11), we obtain the second-order approximation of $h(t, x, y, \mathrm{~T})$.

abstract:
We derive a closed-form approximation for the credit default swap (CDS)
spread in the two-dimensional shifted square-root diffusion (SSRD) model using
asymptotic coefficient expansion technique to approximate solutions of
nonlinear partial differential equations. Specifically, we identify the Cauchy
problems associated with two terms in the CDS spread formula that lack
analytical solutions and derive asymptotic approximations for these terms. Our
approximation does not require the assumption of uncorrelated interest rate and
default intensity processes as typically required for calibration in the SSRD
model. Through several calibration studies using market data on CDS spread, we
demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of our proposed formula.
